[[File:Flag of the Basque Country.svg|thumb|150x|The [[Ikurriña|Basque flag]]]] Since 1912, Spain-based association football club [[Athletic Bilbao]] have had an [[unspoken rule|unwritten rule]] whereby the club will only sign players who were born in the [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque Country]], or who learned their football skills at a Basque club.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/club.html | title = Athletic Club Official Site - Club overview including 'code'}}</ref><ref name=bbc>{{cite web|author=Phil Minshull |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/philminshull/2009/12/colour_barrier_finally_broken.html |title=Colour barrier finally broken at Athletic Bilbao |publisher=BBC |date=2009-12-16 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref name=cien>{{cite news|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/futbol/20111218/54241232095/athletic-bilbao-cien-anos-sin-extranjeros.html|title=Athletic de Bilbao, cien años sin extranjeros|trans-title=Athletic Bilbao, a hundred years without foreigners|language=Spanish|newspaper=[[La Vanguardia]]|date=18 November 2011|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=bbcporque>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2012/05/120508_athletic_bilbao_fain_binda_cch.shtml|title=¿Por qué en el Athletic de Bilbao solo juegan vascos?|trans-title=Why do Athletic Bilbao play with Basques only?|publisher=[[BBC]]|website=BBC Mundo |language=Spanish|date=9 May 2012|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=origin/>
The policy is related to [[Basque nationalism]]<ref name=goss /><ref name=stronghold>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/welcome-to-spains-old-english-outpost-7569163.html|title=Welcome to Spain's old English outpost|last=Unwin|first=Will|newspaper=The Independent|date=15 March 2012|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> and has been praised as a way to promote local talent,<ref>{{cite web|author=Pete Jenson |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/pete-jenson-athletic-bilbao-s-locals-only-transfer-policy-shows-success-does-not-need-to-be-bought-9692663.html |title=Pete Jenson: Athletic Bilbao's locals-only transfer policy shows success does not need to be bought |publisher=The Independent |date=2014-08-26 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> although it has also been criticised as being discriminatory.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=metro>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/05/31/is-athletic-bilbao-basque-only-policy-playing-by-the-rules-3823513/ |title=Is Athletic Bilbao 'Basque-only policy' playing by the rules? |work=Metro |date=2013-05-31 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref>
== History == In the first decade of their existence Athletic selected English players for the team,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://inbedwithmaradona.com/retro/2012/7/4/the-history-of-athletic-bilbao-1898-1936.html|last=Radnedge|first=Keir|title=The history of Athletic Bilbao 1898–1936|magazine=[[World Soccer (magazine)|World Soccer]] (via ''In Bed With Maradona'' website)|date=1 August 1977|accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref><ref name=cien/><ref name=origin/> but since 1912<ref name=Voluntad>{{cite web|url=http://servicios.elcorreo.com/especiales/eleccionesathletic/noticias/not270501a.html|title=Voluntad de tradición|trans-title=Will of tradition|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Correo|date=27 May 2001|accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref> they have adhered to a policy of allowing only players born in the Basque Country or who learned their football skills at a Basque club to play for them.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=sk /><ref name=moyes>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/primera-liga/for-david-moyes-in-basque-derby-identity-and-sovreignty-and-points-all-part-of-the-pressure |title=For David Moyes in Basque derby, identity and sovereignty and points all part of the pressure |newspaper=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |date=25 September 2015 |accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref><ref name=origin/> The motto used to describe the reasoning behind it is "Con cantera y afición, no hace falta importación" (English: "with home-grown talent and local support, you don't need foreigners").<ref name=copa>{{cite web|url=https://copa90.com/this-is-football/17208 |title=This Is Athletic Club de Bilbao |publisher=Copa90.com |date=2016-01-11 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref>
[[File:Basque Country location map.png|thumb|250px|right|location of the '[[Basque Country (greater region)|Greater Basque Country]]' from which Athletic Bilbao recruits all its players]] The policy is not written into the Athletic Bilbao rulebook<ref name=bbcporque/> but has become a philosophy of the club in order to promote local players under the ''[[cantera]]'' (homegrown) system.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=metro /><ref name=copa /> The policy also extends to Athletic's [[Athletic Bilbao B|reserves]], their [[farm team]] [[CD Basconia]], their [[Athletic Bilbao cantera|youth teams]] and their [[Athletic Club Femenino|women's football department]].<ref name=guard>{{cite web|author=Neil Stacey |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/copa90/2016/jan/15/athletic-club-bilbao-loyalty-spain-liga-basque |title=This is Athletic Bilbao: the club whose loyalty to local talent is not negotiable |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> It does not apply to the coaching staff, with managers from England, Hungary, Germany, France and Argentina among those to have led the team at various times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/coaches.html |title=Coaches |publisher=Athletic Bilbao |date=|accessdate=13 February 2018 }}</ref>
They were not the only club to adhere to this approach; fellow Basque club [[Real Sociedad]] had a similar policy from the late 1960s<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=myth/><ref name=special>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/spanish-primera-division/15/blog/post/3312276/athletic-bilbao-real-sociedad-ready-to-renew-a-special-basque-derby-rivalry|title=Athletic Bilbao, Real Sociedad ready to renew a special Basque derby rivalry|last=[[Sid Lowe|Lowe]]|first=Sid|publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=15 December 2017 |accessdate=9 November 2018}}</ref> and won two consecutive league titles in the early 1980s adhering to the self-imposed restriction<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.football-espana.net/clubs/Real%20Sociedad/history |title=Real Sociedad History|publisher=Football España |date=1 August 2017|accessdate=13 February 2018 }}</ref> (as did Athletic),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.football-espana.net/clubs/Athletic%20Bilbao/history |title=Athletic Bilbao History |publisher=Football España |date=1 August 2017|accessdate=13 February 2018 }}</ref> but it was dropped for foreign imports in 1989 when they signed the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] forward [[John Aldridge]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/spanish-primera-division/15/blog/post/2345987/when-john-aldridge-returned-to-real-sociedad-he-got-a-heros-welcome-writes-sid-lowe |title=When John Aldridge returned to Real Sociedad, he got a hero's welcome writes Sid Lowe |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=2015-03-13 |accessdate=2016-09-25}}</ref><ref name=carpet>{{cite web|url= https://as.com/m/diarioas/2015/03/09/english/1425923329_131050.html |title= Real Sociedad roll out the red carpet for John Aldridge |publisher=[[Diario AS]]|date=9 March 2015 |accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref><ref name=moyes/> and for non-Basque Spanish players in 2002 with the transfer of [[Sergio Boris González|Boris]] from [[Real Oviedo]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-06-08-2002/Deportes/boris-acabara-con-30-a%C3%B1os-de-tradicion-en-la-real_119558.html|title=Boris acabará con 30 años de tradición en la Real|trans-title=Boris to end 30-year tradition at Real|language=Spanish|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|date=6 August 2002|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundodeporte/2002/08/13/liga/1029227781.html|title=Boris, primer español no vasco en la Real |trans-title=Boris, first non-Basque Spaniard at Real |language=Spanish|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=13 August 2002|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> However, the [[San Sebastián]]-based club still places a high importance on producing their own local players, and a high percentage of their squad in the 2010s were [[Real Sociedad cantera|home-grown]].<ref name=special/><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/revealed-which-clubs-produce-most-europes-top-players |title=Revealed! Which clubs produce the most of Europe's top players?|publisher=[[FourFourTwo]] |date=1 November 2016 |accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
Back in 1911, a dispute occurred between Real Sociedad and Athletic Bilbao regarding the latter fielding ineligible English players in the [[1911 Copa del Rey]];<ref name=cien/> they had also employed the services of several (non-Basque) players from [[Atlético Madrid]] which was then a branch of the Bilbao club.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://memoriasdelfutbolvasco.wordpress.com/2014/03/30/manuel-garnica/ | title = Manuel Garnica, the "Saint" who scored a goal with Athletic | trans-title =Manuel Garnica, el “Santo” que metió un gol con el Athletic |language=es|website = Memorias del Fútbol Vasco (Memories of Basque Football) | date= 30 March 2014 |accessdate = 15 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.abc.es/20120508/deportes-futbol/abci-historia-athletic-atletico-201205071903.html | title = Athletic-Atlético, historia de dos parientes| trans-title= Athletic-Atlético, history of two relatives| language=es |newspaper = [[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]] | date=8 May 2012|accessdate = 10 October 2018 }}</ref> This led to the [[Royal Spanish Football Federation]] introducing a rule for the next year's competition that all players must be Spanish citizens.<ref name=origin>{{cite web|url=https://www.vavel.com/es/futbol/2017/03/11/real-sociedad/764769-athletic-el-origen-de-la-filosofia.html|title=Athletic Club: el origen de la filosofía|trans-title=Athletic Club: origin of the philosophy| language=Spanish |publisher=[[Vavel]]| date=11 March 2017|accessdate=15 October 2018}}</ref> As a large proportion of the players in that early era were Basque,<ref name=special/> relying on locals was no impediment to Athletic and they chose to maintain that approach even when the regulations were relaxed some years later.
The policy has been praised as a symbol of localised football being successful at the highest level,<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=methods>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11096/10880323/athletic-bilbaos-methods-provide-lessons-for-premier-league-clubs|title=Athletic Bilbao's methods provide lessons for Premier League clubs|publisher=Sky Sports|date=18 May 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> as well as preserving a strong regional identity<ref name=stronghold/><ref name=fox>{{cite web|author=Fox Sports |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/athletic-bilbao-club-all-basque-policy-spain-manchester-united-contrast-030812-2-030812 |title=Quaint anachronism of Athletic Bilbao's Basque nationalism |publisher=FOX Sports |date=2012-03-08 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> and being a way for Basque nationalism to be moderately expressed.<ref name=stronghold/><ref name=goss>{{cite book | first =Brian | last =Goss | title =Identity: Beyond Tradition and McWorld Neoliberalism |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTdQBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA98&dq=1443869074&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXrfS_8pvPAhWkLsAKHWUIDsIQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=1443869074&f=false |publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing |location= | volume = | year = 2014 | isbn = 1443869074 | page =98}}</ref><ref name=fox /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/athletic-bilbao-is-basques-only-and-its-working|title=Athletic Bilbao is 'Basques only' and it's working |publisher=Vice |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref name=special/> It has been described as discriminatory for only allowing Basque players to play for Athletic Bilbao,<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=abre/><ref name=sk>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportskeeda.com/slideshow/football-5-clubs-their-unique-traditions |title=5 football clubs and their unique traditions – Slide 1 of 5 |publisher=Sportskeeda.com |date=2016-01-24 |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> although it has been suggested that the policy is working for them since Athletic are one of only three clubs (along with [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]) never to have been relegated from La Liga.<ref name=stronghold/><ref name=copa /><ref name=guard/>
==Origins of players== ===Ethnic minorities=== [[File:3 de diciembre 2015 Bienvenida al Atlethic de Bilbao 11 (23388774212) (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|130px|[[Iñaki Williams]], of [[West Africa]]n origin but born and raised in the Basque region]] Due to a relatively low immigrant population in the region,<ref name=bbcporque/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://especial.elcorreo.com/2017/extranjeros-euskadi/|title=El origen de los extranjeros que viven en el País Vasco|trans-title=The origin of foreigners living in the Basque Country |language=Spanish|publisher=[[El Correo]] |date=1 January 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=abre>{{cite news|url=https://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20080323/deportes/athletic/athletic-abre-mundo-20080323.html|title=El Athletic se abre al mundo|trans-title=Athletic opens up to the world|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Correo |date=23 March 2008|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> the policy also had the consequence of Athletic Bilbao being the last club in [[La Liga]] to have never fielded a black player. That was ended in 2011 when [[Jonas Ramalho]], whose father is [[Angola]]n, made his debut.<ref name=bbcporque/><ref name=cien/><ref name=myth>[https://www.si.com/more-sports/2011/11/23/jonas Jonas Ramalho helping to dispel longstanding Athletic Bilbao myth]; ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', 23 November 2011</ref> In 2015 [[Iñaki Williams]] (born in Bilbao to [[Immigration to Spain|Liberian immigrant]] parents) became Athletic's first black goalscorer.<ref name=methods/><ref>[http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11827/9723739/inaki-williams-becomes-first-black-athletic-bilbao-goalscorer-in-117-year-history Inaki Williams becomes first black Athletic Bilbao goalscorer in 117-year history]; [[Sky Sports]], 20 February 2015</ref> Prior to Ramalho, in 2000 the first African-born player in the club's youth system was Blanchard Moussayou<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/players/1198/blanchard-mooussayou-sambou.html|title=Blanchard Mooussayou Sambou|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> whose promising career was curtailed by injury; some years later, he stated his belief that it was 'twice as hard' for a black player to make an impact at the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/28239-blanchard-q|title=Blanchard: "El jugador negro tiene aquí doble dificultad" |trans-title=Blanchard: "The black player has double difficulty here"|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Desmarque|date=22 November 2011|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref>
Former academy trainee [[Yuri Berchiche]], who rejoined Athletic in the summer of 2018 as one of the club's most expensive signings,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2018/07/02/5b3a066ae5fdea43378b4650.html|title=Athletic Club seal four-year Yuri Berchiche deal|newspaper=Marca|date=2 July 2018|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref> has an Algerian father but showed no interest in playing for [[Algeria national football team|their national team]] when the matter was put to him.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.algerie-focus.com/2017/12/football-yuri-berchiche-balaie-possibilite-de-defendre-couleurs-de-lalgerie/|title=Football / Yuri Berchiche balaie la possibilité de défendre les couleurs de l'Algérie|trans-title=Football / Yuri Berchiche sweeps the possibility of defending the colours of Algeria|publisher=Algérie Focus|language=fr|date=10 December 2017|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://observalgerie.com/actualite-algerie/sport/equipe-nationale-yuri-berchiche-dit-non-a-lalgerie/|title= Équipe nationale : Yuri Berchiche dit non à l'Algérie|trans-title=National team: Yuri Berchiche says no to Algeria|publisher=ObservAlgerie|language=fr|date=16 April 2018|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref>
As of 2018, Athletic's academy teams include a small number of players of an ethnic minority (mostly [[Afro-Spaniard]]) background, including Cameroon-born goalkeeper [[Chris Atangana]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://as.com/futbol/2017/11/14/primera/1510687840_265078.html |title=Atangana surge entre los sucesores de Arrizabalaga |trans-title=Atangana emerges among the successors of Arrizabalaga |language=Spanish|publisher=Diario AS |date=14 November 2017 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref> forward Nico Williams (the younger brother of Iñaki),<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/63256-nico-sigue-la-estela-de-inaki-williams |title=Nico sigue la estela de Iñaki Williams |trans-title=Nico follows in the wake of Iñaki Williams |language=Spanish|publisher=El Desmarque |date=12 October 2017 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref> and defender Loic Boum, also of [[Cameroon]]ian origin, who having been orphaned as a child was a ward of the [[Government of Navarre]] when he moved to the club in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/noticias/201406/04/lezama-pide-permiso-gobierno-20140604171608.html|title=El Athletic, a por un infantil camerunés de Osasuna |trans-title=Athletic, in for a Cameroonian child from Osasuna |language=Spanish|publisher=El Correo |date=5 June 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lacanteradelezama.com/loic-boum-es-ya-nuevo-jugador-del-athletic/ |title=Loic Boum es ya nuevo jugador del Athletic |trans-title=Loic Boum is now a new Athletic player |language=Spanish|publisher=La Cantera de Lezama |date=4 August 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2018 }}</ref>
===French players=== The club also rarely fielded players from the French [[Northern Basque Country]], with [[Bixente Lizarazu]] being the first French Basque to play for the club in 1996<ref name=cien/><ref name=myth/><ref name=Voluntad/> and [[Aymeric Laporte]] the first to successfully graduate from the [[youth system]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/these-football-times/2014/dec/08/french-basque-country-rugby-heartland-deschamps-lizarazu |title=The French Basque Country: a rugby heartland with world-class footballers |work=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref name=moyes/>
Laporte's signing in 2009 prompted debate regarding the definitions of the policy, as he had no link to the Basque region through birth or residency, and a blood link only via [[Grandparent#Great-grandparents|great-grandparents]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/36668-laporte-tengo-sangre-vasca-por-parte-de-mis-bisabuelos |title=Laporte: "Tengo sangre vasca por parte de mis bisabuelos" |trans-title=Laporte: "I have Basque blood through my great-grandparents" |publisher=El Desmarque |language=Spanish|date=25 July 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=among>{{cite web |url=http://onlyfootball.fr/?p=513 |title=Aymeric Laporte, un Basque parmi les Basques |trans-title=Aymeric Laporte, a Basque among the Basques |publisher=Only Football |language=French|date=14 May 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=butterflies>{{cite web |url=http://www.sofoot.com/aymeric-laporte-a-arrete-de-regarder-les-papillons-173450.html |title=Aymeric Laporte a "arrêté de regarder les papillons" |trans-title=Aymeric Laporte "stopped watching the butterflies” |publisher=So Foot |language=French |date=26 September 2013|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=moyes/> He did join a team in the territory, [[Aviron Bayonnais FC|Aviron Bayonnais]],<ref name=ownbio>{{cite web |url=http://www.aymericlaporte.com/en/bio/|title=Biography - Athletic Bilbao signing and beginnings|trans-title=|work=Aymeric Laporte official website |date=|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=butterflies/> but only by arrangement after the initial approach from Athletic, as he was too young to move to a club outside France at the time – he arrived formally in 2010.<ref name=methods/>
{{ill|Yanis Rahmani|eu}}, a [[Algerians in France|Frenchman of Algerian origin]] raised in [[Sestao]],<ref name=abre/> progressed as far as Basconia at the same time as Laporte but did not turn professional with the club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mirandes.elcorreo.com/noticias/201706/27/extremo-zurdo-yanis-rahmani-20170626234606.html |title=El extremo zurdo Yanis Rahmani se incorpora al Mirandés para las dos próximas temporadas |trans-title=The left winger Yanis Rahmani joins the Mirandés for the next two seasons|language=Spanish|newspaper =El Correo|date=27 June 2017|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref>
====Griezmann debate==== [[Antoine Griezmann]], the French forward developed by Real Sociedad, was the subject of debate regarding his eligibility for a theoretical move to Athletic as he emerged as an elite player in 2012.<ref name=impossible/> Hailing from [[Bourgogne-Franche-Comté|Burgundy]], he arrived at the San Sebastián club aged 14<ref name=antoine>{{cite web|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/griezmann-not-interested-bilbao-speculation|title=Griezmann not interested in Bilbao speculation|publisher=FourFourTwo|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> but only to play football for their academy teams rather than for some other non-sporting reason, and has no connection to the French Basque Country other than attending school there after signing for Real.
The opinions of some (including Athletic's academy director [[José María Amorrortu]]) <ref name=impossible>{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2017/01/19/5880a91522601d4a498b4577.html |title=Athletic Club's impossible dream of signing Griezmann |newspaper=Marca|date=19 January 2017|accessdate=3 February 2018}}</ref> were that his training at a Basque club from a young age adhered to the policy,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eitb.eus/es/deportes/futbol/athletic/detalle/900544/el-athletic-interesado-antoine-griezmann--real-sociedad/|title=¿Puede fichar el Athletic a Griezmann?|trans-title=Can Athletic sign Griezmann?|language=Spanish|publisher=EITB|date=6 June 2012|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> while others insisted that he had the same (ineligible) status as any adult player transferred in by Real and the other local professional clubs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/es/news/4194/editoriales/2012/09/28/3407931/antoine-griezmann-no-entra-en-la-filosof%C3%ADa-del-athletic-de|title=Antoine Griezmann no entra en la filosofía del Athletic de Bilbao|trans-title=Antoine Griezmann does not enter the philosophy of Athletic Bilbao|language=Spanish|publisher=Goal|date=28 September 2012|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref>
In any event, Griezmann showed little interest in joining Athletic,<ref name=antoine/> subsequently moved on to [[Atlético Madrid]]<ref name=impossible/> and was voted the [[2016 Ballon d'Or|world's third best player]] in 2016,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/12/cristiano-ronaldo-ballon-dor-fourth-lionel-messi|title=Cristiano Ronaldo wins Ballon d’Or for the fourth time|date=12 December 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> making any move to Bilbao unlikely in the medium term. In respect of any future players of a similar trajectory, Athletic's position on recruitment remains unconfirmed.
===Players of Basque descent=== [[File:Fernando Amorebieta.png|thumb|right|120px|[[Fernando Amorebieta]], born in Venezuela but raised in the Basque Country]] In 1980 the club was believed to have given serious consideration to signing [[Iker Zubizarreta]], a young [[Venezuelan people|Venezuelan]] of Basque heritage (his grandfather [[Félix Zubizarreta|Félix]] had starred for Athletic in the 1910s) who had impressed at the [[Football at the 1980 Summer Olympics|football tournament]] at the [[1980 Summer Olympics]], but decided not to pursue it.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.naiz.eus/en/hemeroteca/gara/editions/2015-08-06/hemeroteca_articles/iker-zubizarreta-el-nieto-de-leon-que-pudo-ser-cachorro|title=Iker Zubizarreta: el nieto de león que pudo ser cachorro |trans-title=Iker Zubizarreta: grandson of a lion who could have been a puppy|language=Spanish|publisher=[[Gara]]|date=6 August 2015|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
In 2011, media sources claimed that Athletic had shown interest in young [[Mexican people|Mexican]] midfielder [[Jonathan Espericueta]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2011/06/26/mas_futbol/1309069655_850215.html |title=Interés por el mexicano Espericueta|trans-title=Interest in the Mexican Espericueta |language=Spanish |publisher=[[Diario AS]] |date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> but no such move materialised, and the player himself (who did later play in Spain with [[Villarreal CF B|Villarreal B]]) stated that his Basque connection was as distant as a great-great-grandfather.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elnuevoheraldo.com/deportes/le-dice-no-a-europa/article_2016b80d-0ccd-5b95-864d-f60cca06d84c.html |title=Le dice 'no' a Europa |trans-title=He says "no" to Europe |language=Spanish |publisher=[[El Nuevo Heraldo]] |date=23 June 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
The [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguayan international]] [[Diego Forlán]], whose paternal grandmother was Basque, claimed he had talks over a potential transfer to the club in 2004<ref>{{cite news|title=Forlán afirma que negoció su fichaje por el Athletic|trans-title=Forlán confirms that he negotiated a transfer to Athletic|url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/noticias/2010-09-14/forlan-hubo-contactos-athletic-201009141353.html|accessdate=18 March 2017|work=[[El Correo]] |date=14 September 2010|language=Spanish}}</ref> but this signing would have been incompatible with the club's current policy as Forlan was not born in a Basque region, nor did he play football as a youth (or at any point in his career) at a club in the territory. That is also true of [[Argentinian people|Argentinian]] forward [[Gonzalo Higuaín]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/1a_division/athletic/es/desarrollo/661629.html|title=La sorpresa de Lamikiz podría ser un extremo argentino de River Plate|trans-title=The surprise of Lamikiz could be an Argentine winger from River Plate|language=Spanish|newspaper=Marca|date=21 June 2006|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> and Spaniards [[Benjamín Zarandona]],<ref name=myth/><ref name=bbcporque/> [[Kepa Blanco]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elcorreo.com/vizcaya/20070628/deportes/athletic/macua-prefiere-cerrar-nido-20070628.html|title=Macua prefiere cerrar con Del Nido la compra de Kepa antes de negociar con el jugador|trans-title=Macua prefers to conclude the purchase of Kepa with Del Nido before negotiating with the player|language=Spanish|newspaper=El This contrasts with players who were signed by the club such as [[Higinio Ortúzar]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.martiperarnau.com/higinio-ortuzar-el-chileno-de-sangre-vasca/|title=Higinio Ortúzar: [[File:Rrios2013002.jpg|thumb|left|120px|[[Roberto Ríos]], born in Bilbao but raised and trained in [[Seville]]]] Conversely, players born in the Basque Country but raised elsewhere are considered eligible.<ref name=myth/> [[Fernando Llorente]] was born in Pamplona<ref name=oyon/> but lived his whole childhood in [[Rincón de Soto]] (close to Basque territory but outside it) before he was recruited as an 11-year-old.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hemeroteca.elmundodeportivo.es/preview/2005/01/18/pagina-24/1532732/pdf.html|title=Fue todo tan rápido que ni me lo creía|trans-title=Everything was so fast I could not believe it|newspaper=[[Mundo Deportivo]]|language=Spanish|date=18 January 2005|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> Two of Athletic's most expensive signings, the Bilbao-born [[Spain national football team|Spain internationals]] [[Roberto Ríos]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elmundo.es/1997/07/20/deportes/20N0074.html|title=Ríos y el Athletic pasan a la historia|trans-title=Ríos and Athletic make history|language=Spanish|publisher=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=20 July 1997|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> and [[Ander Herrera]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/877509/athletic-bilbao-confirm-deal-to-sign-ander-herrera?cc=5739 |title=Athletic confirm Herrera deal|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=7 February 2011|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> learned their skills in the cities where their footballing fathers were based professionally ([[Eusebio Ríos|Eusebio]] at [[Real Betis]] of [[Seville]], and [[Pedro María Herrera|Pedro]] at [[Real Zaragoza]] respectively); [[Gaizka Mendieta]] (son of [[Andrés Mendieta]] of [[CD Castellón]]) had similar origins but turned down a move,<ref name=pain>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2003/aug/24/sport.comment2|title=Leaving the pain in Spain |publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 August 2003|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> albeit he remained a proud Basque who played for the [[Basque Country national football team|unofficial representative team]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eff-fvf.eus/pub/verFichaPartido.asp?idioma=ca&idPartido=139|title=Euskadi 5–1 Nigeria| publisher=[[Basque Country national football team|Euskadiko Futbol Federakundea]]| language=Spanish|date=29 November 1999|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
In the years prior to the [[Spanish Civil War]], Athletic undertook a project named 'Operation Return', seeking players born in the Basque region who had emigrated to other countries. One of the few who actually made a competitive appearance for the club was [[:es:Nemesio Tamayo|Nemesio Tamayo]] who had begun his career in his adopted homeland of Chile and also played in Mexico before a brief spell in his birthplace.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://jonrivas7.wixsite.com/athletic/single-post/2016/1/17/Tamayo-el-primero-de-la-Operaci%C3%B3n-Retorno |title=La Operación Retorno de 1934 |trans-title=The Operation Return of 1934 |work=El Mundo |language=es |via=Historia Rojiblancas |date=17 January 2016 |accessdate=23 November 2018 }}</ref> The arrival of Bilbao-born [[Emilio Aldecoa]] in 1947 was unusual as he had spent the past decade of his life in England, having been evacuated as a teenage refugee of the Civil War.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Spanish refugee boy 78 years ago blazed the trail for David Silva and Cesc Fabregas |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/a-spanish-refugee-boy-78-years-ago-blazed-the-trail-for-david-silva-and-cesc-fabregas-10488958.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=6 September 2015|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=First foreign footballers: Spain’s Emilio Aldecoa|url=https://www.football365.com/news/first-foreign-footballers-spains-emilio-aldecoa |website=Football365|date=16 March 2018|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Into the ether: When football welcomed refugees|url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/blogs/ether/when-football-welcomed-refugees |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |date=26 April 2017|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> Another member of that refugee group was the club's star goalkeeper of the era [[Raimundo Pérez Lezama]], although he had returned home much sooner on the outbreak of [[World War II]]; a third Basque refugee [[Sabino Barinaga]] turned down an offer from Athletic and joined [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].<ref>{{cite web|title=El momento histórico|trans-title=The historic moment|url=http://algomasquefutbol.blogspot.pt/2007/02/el-momento-histrico.html||website=Algo Más que Fútbol|date=6 February 2007|accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref>
===Players from Biscay=== It was once the case that Athletic would usually recruit from the [[Biscay]] province surrounding [[Bilbao]]<ref name=myth/> while the other leading clubs Real Sociedad and [[CA Osasuna|Osasuna]] would focus on players from their respective provinces [[Gipuzkoa]] and [[Navarre]]. In recent decades (with the pool of potential players declining due to a low birth rate in the area),<ref name=lehendakari/> Athletic expanded their recruitment in these other areas in their efforts to accommodate the best players with any Basque links. This saw many talented players from [[San Sebastián]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://real-sociedad.diariovasco.com/noticias/201610/13/hasta-trece-transfugas-defendido-20161013005246-v.html|title=Real Sociedad: Hasta trece tránsfugas han defendido las dos camisetas|trans-title=Up to thirteen 'traitors' have defended the two shirts|newspaper=[[El Diario Vasco]]|language=Spanish|date=13 October 2016|accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> and [[Pamplona]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://real-sociedad.diariovasco.com/noticias/2011-02-10/chantrea-mejor-vivero-athletic-20110210.html |title=La Chantrea, el mejor vivero, es del Athletic |trans-title=Chantrea, Athletic's best nursery |language=Spanish |publisher=[[El Diario Vasco]]|date= 10 February 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2018}}</ref> join the club, and also caused Real Sociedad to abandon their own Basque policy in the face of the competition for signings.<ref name=morboreview>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2001/mar/26/newsstory.sport13|title=Morbo: The Story of Spanish Football by Phil Ball (London: WSC Books, 2001)|date=26 March 2001|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|last=[[Sid Lowe|Lowe]]|first=Sid}}</ref><ref name=moyes/>

That change of focus also led to fewer players from the home province being selected; in a 2011 fixture, none of the Athletic starters or substitutes were from Biscay.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.footballwhispers.com/blog/athletic-bilbaos-transfer-policy| title = Football Whispers – Athletic Bilbao’s transfer policy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/match-statistics/1_4456/2010-11_real-zaragoza_athletic-club.html| title = Real Zaragoza 2 Athletic Club 1 02/03/2011|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> However, in subsequent years more local players made the grade, and the situation appears unlikely to occur again in the near future – twelve of the 25 players in the [[2016–17 Athletic Bilbao season#Squad|2016–17 squad]] were born in Biscay, and in November 2017 a study showed that 77% of players in the academy teams hailed from the province.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/64416-el-77-de-canteranos-del-athletic-son-vizcainos|title=El 77% de canteranos del Athletic son vizcaínos|trans-title=77% of Athletic homegrown players are from Biscay|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Desmarque|date=27 November 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref>
===Players from outside the region=== On the other hand, the definitions of the philosophy are stretched occasionally to accommodate promising youngsters with little Basque connection, which does not always sit well with some of the club's followers.
[[Enric Saborit]], originally from [[Catalonia]], who graduated through the youth and reserve levels to reach the first team, caused questions to be asked when he signed in 2008; he had no connection with the region by birth or blood, but while already 16 years old and playing in [[RCD Espanyol]]'s ''cantera'' teams, he moved to [[Vitoria-Gasteiz]] where his mother had relocated for work two years earlier. As soon as he became a resident of the territory, Saborit was deemed eligible by Athletic to play for the club.<ref name=debate>{{cite news |url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/1a_division/athletic/es/desarrollo/1094438.html |title=Saborit abre el debate de la filosofía del club |trans-title=Saborit opens debate on club philosophy |publisher=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=Spanish|date=27 February 2008 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=abre/><ref name=catalan>{{cite news |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/futbol/20170104/413083135665/saborit-catalan-athletic.html |title=Saborit, un catalán en el Athletic |trans-title=Saborit, a Catalan at Athletic|publisher=[[La Vanguardia]]|language=Spanish|date=5 January 2017 |accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
In summer 2017, Athletic recruited Youssouf Diarra, an 18-year-old forward born in Mali who was raised in Catalonia and had spent the past two years playing for clubs in Navarre after moving these to continue his education, which the club deemed sufficient under the policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacanteradelezama.com/youssouf-diarra-se-incorporara-al-basconia/|title=Youssouf Diarra se incorporará al Basconia |trans-title=Youssouf Diarra to join Basconia|publisher=La Cantera De Lezama|language=Spanish|date=24 June 2017|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://as.com/futbol/2017/02/03/primera/1486092170_940650.amp.html |title=La prueba del malí Diarra pone en marcha el debate filosófico |trans-title=The trial of Malian Diarra launches a philosophical debate |newspaper=Diario AS|language=Spanish|date=3 February 2017|accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/61585-ander-alana-si-diarra-esta-aqui-entra-en-la-filosofia|title=Ander Alaña: "Si Diarra está aquí entra en la filosofía"|trans-title=Ander Alaña: "If Diarra is here he enters the philosophy"|publisher=El Desmarque|language=Spanish|date=23 July 2017|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref> The previous year they had web|url=http://www.lacanteradelezama.com/el-juvenil-deiby-ochoa-nuevo-fichaje-desde-el-comillas-cf/|title=El juvenil Deiby Ochoa nuevo fichaje desde el Comillas CF|trans-title=The junior Deiby Ochia centenaria filosofia trayendo a Lezama a jovenes de fuera de Euskal Herria|trans-title=Athletic throws out their century-old philosophy bringing youngsters to Lezama from outside the Basque Country|publisher=Orain.eus|language=Spanish|date=22 June 2016|accessdate=4 August 2017}}</ref> Both players had attended trial matches at the [[Lezama Facilities|Lezama]] training centre.
However, despite having invited Ochoa (the spelling of whose name was changed to the Basque ''Otxoa'' in club records) to join,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/players/2549/otxoa.html|title=Deiby Otxoa profile|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> in October 2017 it was announced that Athletic's youth training camp in [[Oyón-Oion|Oion]] – a village in [[Álava]], but just a few miles from [[Logroño]] – would no longer accept players who did not fit the Athletic philosophy, effectively excluding around 150 Riojan youngsters of various ages from the system and leaving only around ten Basques across the squads.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/deportes/futbol/20171021/432229155688/athletic-oyon-la-rioja.html|title=El Athletic expulsa a 150 canteranos por su procedencia riojana|trans-title=Athletic expels 150 canteranos for their Riojan origin|language=Spanish|newspaper=La Vanguardia|date=21 October 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/athletic-expulsa-cantera-20171021223007-nt.html|title=El Athletic no admitirá a niños riojanos en su escuela alavesa de Oion|trans-title=Athletic will not admit children from La Rioja in their Alavese school at Oion|language=Spanish|newspaper=El Correo|date=21 October 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref><ref name=oyon/> Past recruits born in that region, who were considered eligible due to their formative club being Osasuna or Real Sociedad, include [[José Mari García]], [[Santiago Ezquerro]], [[David López (footballer, born 1982)|David López]] and [[Borja Viguera]]; however, the justifications for allowing [[Luis de la Fuente Castillo|Luis de la Fuente]] and later [[Daniel Aranzubia]] to join Athletic's youth system directly from Riojan clubs were less clear.<ref name=oyon>{{Cite news|url=https://www.larioja.com/deportes/futbol/llorente-haber-oyon-20171020002918-ntvo.html|title=Llorente sí podría haber ido a Oyón |trans-title=Llorente could have gone to Oyón|newspaper=La Rioja|date=26 October 2017 |accessdate=29 November 2018|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In January 2018, Athletic announced a new signing who was more obviously non-Basque by ethnicity: 25-year-old [[Cristian Ganea]], a [[Romania national football team|Romanian international]]<ref name="Athletic_Bilbao_transfer">{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.eus/en/news/18649/cristian-ganea-initial-agreement-with-fc-viitorul.html|title=Cristian Ganea: Initial agreement with FC Viitorul|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref> who was also born in that country and had only played for Romanian clubs for the past five years. But prior to that, he had spent his teenage years living in [[Basauri]] just outside Bilbao and had featured for local teams (including [[CD Basconia|Basconia]], Athletic's farm team at semi-professional level who have a separate amateur and juvenile structure), meaning he too was eligible under the 'learned skills at a Basque club' aspect of the policy.<ref name=abcficha>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/deportes/futbol/abci-athletic-ficha-ganea-primer-rumano-historia-201801151632_noticia.html|title=El Athletic ficha a Cristian Ganea, el primer rumano de su historia|trans-title=Athletic sign Cristian Ganea, the first Romanian in their history|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=mundoficha>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/deportes/futbol/2018/01/15/5a5cac83ca47419e778b4645.html|title=El Athletic ficha al internacional rumano Cristian Ganea|trans-title=Athletic sign the Romanian international Cristian Ganea|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=15 January 2018|accessdate=16 January 2018|language=Spanish}}</ref>

El Nacional]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mifutbolecuador.wordpress.com/2012/01/23/todos-las-participaciones-internacionales-de-el-nacional/|title=Todos las participaciones internacionales de El Nacional|trans-title=All the international participations of El Nacional|language=Spanish|website=El Blog de mi Futbol Ecuatoriano|date=23 January 2012|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> an Ecuadorian club who only field players from that nation *[[Euskaltel–Euskadi]], defunct Basque cycling team with similar rider hiring policy

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name = Border Patrol Police
(ตำรวจตระเวนชายแดน) |image = Bpplogo.jpg |image_size = 180px |caption = Border Patrol Police |dates = 1951–present |country = Thailand |allegiance = |branch= [[Royal Thai Police]] |type = [[Paramilitary]] force |role = Border Security
Counter-insurgency |size = |garrison = |nickname =Tor. Chor. Dor. (ต.ช.ด.) |motto = |colors = |march = |mascot = |battles = |anniversaries = |decorations = |notable_commanders = |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |dissolution = |command_structure1 = [[Royal Thai Armed Forces]] |command_structure2 = |old_name = |honneur = |inscriptions = |equipement = |commander = |commander_label = }} The '''Border Patrol Police''' ({{lang-th|ตำรวจตระเวนชายแดน)}}; (BPP) is a [[Thailand|Thai]] [[paramilitary]] under the jurisdiction of the [[Royal Thai Police]], responsible for [[Border guard|border security]] and [[counter-insurgency]]. ==History== The Thai Border Patrol Police was organized in the 1951 with assistance from the [[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]. Although technically part of the [[Royal Thai Police]] (RTP), the BPP has always enjoyed a great deal of autonomy within the national headquarters as well as in its field operations. The royal family was a principal patron of the organization. This traditional relationship benefited both the palace and its paramilitary protectors. Many BPP commanders were former army officers.http://www.country-data.com/cgi-bin/query/r-13813.html ==Organization== [[File:ชุดเต็ม๑.JPG|thumb|Thai Border Patrol Police uniform]] [[File:BorderPatrolPoliceColours.JPG|thumb|Presenting Border Patrol Police Colours]] [[File:PoliceColours (6).jpg|thumb|Border Patrol Police Colours]] ===National Organization=== *Headquarters Border Patrol Police Bureau **General Staff Division *Special Training Division *Support Division *[[Border Patrol Police#Border Patrol Police Aerial Reinforcement Unit|Police Aerial Reinforcement Unit]] (PARU) **[[Naresuan 261 Counter-Terrorism Unit]] *Village Scout Center *BPP Regional Divisions 1, 2, 3, and 4. ===Field organization=== Platoons of 32-men form the basic operating units of the BPP. Each platoon is supported by one or more heavy weapons platoons stationed at the regional and area RTP headquarters. PARU can airlift BPP platoons to troubled areas when an emergency arises. Armed with modern light infantry equipment, the BPP also benefited from training by [[United States Army Special Forces]] advisers who helped establish an instruction program during the 1960s. The BPP served as an important adjunct to the Thai military and often operated under army (and sometimes the [[Royal Thai Marine Corps]]) control during counterinsurgency operations. BPP units stationed along the Cambodian and Laotian borders following the [[Cambodia–Vietnam relations#Cambodian-Vietnamese War|Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia in 1979]] often served as a first line of defense and bore the brunt of [[Vietnamese border raids in Thailand|Vietnamese attacks]]. In order to carry out its intelligence mission, the BPP operates numerous [[civic action program]]s to cultivate and maintain rapport with remote area villagers and hill tribes. They have built and operate schools in remote areas and help the army construct offices for civilian administration. They operate rural medical aid stations, give farmers agricultural assistance, and have built small airstrips. ===Border Patrol Police Aerial Reinforcement Unit=== The Border Patrol Police Parachute Aerial Resupply Unit (BPP PARU or PARU) is the BPP's [[special forces]] unit responsible for training and supporting airborne operations, airborne reinforcement, disaster and accident rescue, and supporting special missions under the command of the BPP. All members of PARU are trained for airborne operations, including free-fall jumps. PARU can provide support to BPP headquarters within two hours. The PARU in the 1950s and 1960s was a small unit used for clandestine missions outside Thailand. It was largely [[CIA]]-funded at that time.{{cite book|last1=Rattanasengchanh|first1=Phimmasone Michael|title=Thailand's Second Triumvirate: Sarit Thanarat and the military, King Bhumibol Adulyadej and the monarchy and the United States. 1957-1963| date=2012|publisher=University of Washington|location=Seattle|url=https://digital.lib.washington.edu/researchworks/bitstream/handle/1773/21997/Rattanasengchanh_washington_0250O_10615.pdf?sequence=1|accessdate=26 April 2017|format=MA Thesis}}{{RP|51}} PARU's counts its founding from 27 April 1954, when King Bhumibol visited the opening ceremony of the PARU Company's [[Naresuan Camp]] in [[Hua Hin]].{{cite book |last1=Hyun |first1=Sinae |title=Indigenizing the Cold War: Nation - Building by the Border Patrol Police of Thailand, 1945 - 1980 |date=2014 |publisher=University of Wisconsin |location=Madison |url=https://depot.library.wisc.edu/repository/fedora/1711.dl:JKW6YYIA5ESL28Y/datastreams/REF/content |accessdate=15 August 2018 |format=Dissertation}}{{RP|92}} PARU also conducts training for the following: * unconventional warfare, counter-terrorism, and parachute training of the Royal Thai Police. * disaster and accident rescue on land and water including [[air-sea rescue]]. ==Subordinate paramilitary forces== ===Volunteer Defense Corps=== {{main|Volunteer Defense Corps (Thailand)}} {{refimprove section|date=October 2012}} The BPP organized the paramilitary Volunteer Defense Corps or VDC (the ''Or Sor'') in 1954 to provide law and order and emergency response. This was done in response to complaints of banditry and harassment by subversive organizations. The VDC had the responsibility of protecting inhabitants from threats and intimidation by guerrillas who had infiltrated the border provinces from neighboring Laos, Cambodia, and Malaysia. Its mission is to deny insurgents access to food and other supplies that made villages and farms their targets. VDC members were trained by the BPP. In 1974 it was expanded by the [[Internal Security Operations Command]] (ISOC) to urban areas to fight left-wing political activism. In the late 1980s, VDC strength was estimated at roughly 33,000, down from a peak of about 52,000 in 1980. Part of the reduction was absorbed by the formation of the Thahan Phran, a paramilitary unit formed to counter communist insurgents. They were reinvigorated and have played a role in the fighting the [[South Thailand insurgency]] since 2004.{{Citation |title=Southern Thailand: The Problem with Paramilitaries |journal=Asia Report |number=140 |date=23 October 2007 |publisher=International Crisis Group |pages=14–15 |url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/asia/south-east-asia/thailand/140_southern_thailand___the_problem_with_paramilitaries.ashx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208035841/http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/asia/south-east-asia/thailand/140_southern_thailand___the_problem_with_paramilitaries.ashx |archivedate=8 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }} ===Village Scouts=== {{main|Village Scouts}} The BPP, together with the [[Ministry of Interior (Thailand)|Ministry of Interior]], backed and sponsored the 1971 establishment of the "[[Village Scouts]]", a right-wing rural vigilante group and paramilitary militia.{{Citation |first=Benedict |last=Anderson |title=The Spectre of Comparisons: Nationalism, Southeast Asia, and the World |publisher=Verso |year=1998 |page=159}} The village scouts were to counter the [[Communist Party of Thailand|communist insurgency]] and the pro-democracy movement of the 1970s. Soon after its creation, five million Thais (10 percent of the population) went through the organisation's initiation rite and took its five-day training course.{{Citation needed|date=June 2016}} The Village Scouts conducted the anti-leftist rally that led to the [[Thammasat University massacre]] and bloody coup d'état on 6 October 1976.{{Citation |first=Somboon |last=Suksamran |title=Buddhism and politics in Thailand |publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies |year=1982 |pages=79–80}} The Village Scouts disappeared around 1981, but were revived around 2004 against the backdrop of the [[South Thailand insurgency|Muslim separatist conflict]] in south Thailand.{{Citation |first=Alexander |last=Horstmann |title=Violence, Subversion and Creativity in the Thai-Malaysian Borderland |work=Borderscapes: Hidden Geographies and Politics at Territory's Edge |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |year=2007 |page=149}} The village scout concept was extended to {{lang|th|ลูกเสือบนเครือข่ายอินเทอร์เน็ต}} ('Village Scouts on the Internet') internet activities with the creation of the "cyber scouts".{{cite web |url=http://asiapacific.anu.edu.au/newmandala/2010/07/02/from-village-scouts-to-cyber-scouts/ |title=From Village Scouts to Cyber Scouts |author=Nicholas Farrelly |date=2 July 2010 |work=New Mandala |accessdate=10 February 2011}} ===Thahan Phran=== {{main|Thahan Phran}} The 10,600 member Thahan Phran ("Rangers") was formed as a volunteer [[militia]] force deployed to active trouble spots along the Cambodian and Burmese borders. The paramilitary organization had 32 regiments and 196 companies. The Thahan Phran gained considerable publicity and incurred significant casualties during [[Vietnamese border raids in Thailand|Vietnamese bombardments and local assaults]] along the Cambodian border.Ball D. ''The Boys in Black: The Thahan Phran (Rangers), Thailand's Para-Military Border Guards.'' Bangkok, Thailand: White Lotus Press, 2004. Since 2004, they have deployed to counter the [[South Thailand insurgency]].{{Citation |title=Southern Thailand: The Problem with Paramilitaries |journal=Asia Report |number=140 |date=23 October 2007 |publisher=International Crisis Group |pages=4–13 |url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/asia/south-east-asia/thailand/140_southern_thailand___the_problem_with_paramilitaries.ashx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208035841/http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/asia/south-east-asia/thailand/140_southern_thailand___the_problem_with_paramilitaries.ashx |archivedate=8 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }} ==See also== * [[Royal Thai Police]] ** [[Naresuan 261 Counter-Terrorism Unit]] * [[Internet censorship in Thailand]] * [[Nawaphon]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{CIA World Factbook|year=2004}} * [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/th.html CIA World Factbook page] ==External links== {{Commons category|Police of Thailand}} *[http://www.police.go.th Official Royal Thai Police website] {{th icon}} *[http://www.nationreligionking.com English Information on the Royal Thai Police] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091026233420/http://geocities.com/bpp_92/ Border Patrol Police Subdivision 92 (PARU) Unofficial page] {{th icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091027035844/http://geocities.com/thaipolairborne/ Border Patrol Police Airborne Reinforcement Unit (PARU)] {{th icon}} {{Military of Thailand}} {{Special forces of Thailand}} {{Government of Thailand|state=collapsed}} {{Border guards}} [[Category:Law enforcement in Thailand]] [[Category:Paramilitary organizations based in Thailand]] [[Category:Border guards]] [[Category:Borders of Thailand]] [[Category:1950s establishments in Thailand]]

{{Infobox military award |name = Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal |image = CPSM_Medal.jpg |image_size = 100px |caption = The obverse and reverse of the medal |awarded_by =the
[[File:Canadian Coat of Arms Shield.svg|30px]]
[[Monarchy of Canada|monarch of Canada]] |type = Medal |eligibility = |for = A minimum of 30 days cumulative service in a UN or international peacekeeping mission. |status = Currently awarded |description = |clasps = |established = 2000 |first_award = 6 September 2000 |last_award = |total = |posthumous = |recipients = 68,000 |individual = |higher = [[Special Service Medal (Canada)|Special Service Medal]] |same = |lower = [[United Nations Korea Medal]] |image2 = [[File:CPSM Ribbon.png|150px]] |caption2 = Ribbon of the Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal }} The '''Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal''' ({{lang-fr|Médaille canadienne du maintien de la paix}}) is a [[campaign medal]] created in 1988 to recognize the contributions of all Canadian [[Peacekeeping|Peacekeepers]] towards the ultimate goal of peace,{{cite web| url=http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhr-ddhr/chc-tdh/chart-tableau-eng.asp?ref=CPSM| last=Department of National Defence| authorlink=Department of National Defence (Canada)| title=DH&R Home > Canadian Honours Chart > Canadian Peace Keeping Service Medal (CPSM)| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=31 October 2009}} after the [[United Nations]] [[Department of Peacekeeping Operations]] was awarded that year's [[Nobel Peace Prize]]. ==History== In 1988, the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] was awarded to United Nations Peacekeepers, in recognition of their efforts over more than 50 years to establish and maintain peace.{{cite book|author=Christopher McCreery|title=The Canadian honours system|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nI9qJsEsT6gC&pg=PA181|date=24 March 2005|publisher=Dundurn Press Ltd.|isbn=978-1-55002-554-5|page=181}} This act inspired the creation of the Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal, its purpose being to recognize all [[Canadians]], including serving and former members of the [[Canadian Forces]], members of the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]], other police services, and Canadian [[civilians]], who contributed to peace on certain missions. Some time was involved in getting the medal to the presentation stage, but, as with the creation of any major honour or award, the approval of this award involved consultation with a large number of interested individuals. ==Design== The Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal was designed by [[Bruce W. Beatty]] and is in the form of a {{convert|36|mm|in}} diameter [[Disk (mathematics)|disc]] with, on the obverse, the words ''PEACEKEEPING • SERVICE DE LA PAIX'', separated by maple leaves, surrounding a rendition of the three Canadian Peacekeeper figures that top the [[Peacekeeping Monument]] in [[Ottawa]]; one is an unarmed [[United Nations]] Military Observer, holding [[binoculars]], the second, a woman, shoulders a [[radio]], while the third stands guard with a [[rifle]], and above them is a [[dove]], the international symbol of peace. The medal's reverse shows the word ''CANADA'' below a maple leaf surrounded by a laurel wreath and bearing the [[Royal Cypher]] of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], symbolizing her roles as both [[fount of honour]] and [[Commander-in-Chief]] of her various forces.{{cite web| url=http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhr-ddhr/chc-tdh/chart-tableau-eng.asp?ref=SM| last=Department of National Defence| authorlink=Department of National Defence (Canada)| title=DH&R Home > Canadian Honours Chart > Sacrifice Medal (SM)| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=2 September 2009| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091114162425/http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhr-ddhr/chc-tdh/chart-tableau-eng.asp?ref=SM#| archive-date=2009-11-14| dead-url=yes| df=}} A single-toe claw attaches the top of the medal to the centre of a slotted bar on which is another maple leaf. This medallion is worn at the left chest, suspended on a 31.8mm wide ribbon coloured with vertical stripes in the shade of blue used by the United Nations, green (representing service), and Canada's official colours: red (also indicitave of blood shed in the service of peace), and white (also the colour of peace). ==Eligibility== The Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal recognizes Canadian Peacekeepers deployed outside Canada for a minimum of 30 days, which includes members of the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]], other police officers, and civilians who served with the forces on peacekeeping missions. As of September 2003, some 68,000 Peacekeeping Service Medals had been awarded. ==See also== * [[Canadian order of precedence (decorations and medals)]] * [[Peace Prize Medal (Denmark)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C-21.1/page-1.html Canadian Peacekeeping Service Medal Act] {{Canadian Honours System}} [[Category:Civil awards and decorations of Canada]] [[Category:Canadian campaign medals]] [[Category:Peacekeeping]]

{{Infobox person |name = Catherine Feuillet |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Catherine Feuillet |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1965|7}} |birth_place = [[Orléans]], France |nationality = French |alma_mater = Federal Institute for Agroecology in Zurich |occupation = Geneticist and Molecular Biologist |known_for = Sequencing chromosome 3B on the wheat genome |awards = Prix Foulon, Trophée de la Femme, Chevalier of the Legion of Honour, Jean Dufrenoy Prize from the Académie d'Agriculture of France }} '''Catherine Feuillet''' ({{IPA-fr|katʁin fœjɛ|-|Fr-Catherine Feuillet.ogg}}; born July 1965) is a French [[geneticist]] who is the head of trait research at [[Bayer CropScience]] and a co-chair of the International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium (IWGSC). Feuillet has been working on plant genetics since 1994 when she completed post-doctoral studies at the Swiss Federal Institute for Agroecology. She wrote her thesis on Lignification of Eucalyptus which is the study of how wood is formed on a cellular basis. After that she moved on to the University of Zurich in 1997 where she was a junior group leader investigating fungal disease resistance in plant genomes. In 2008, she and her team successfully published the first mapping of the largest wheat chromosome, 3B and in 2014, they successfully completed mapping 3B's sequencing and published a draft of the entire wheat genome. She has been awarded the Prix Foulon from the French Academy of Science, the gold ''Trophée de la Femme'', was honored as a Chevalier of the [[Legion of Honour]], and received the Jean Dufrenoy Prize from the [[Académie d'Agriculture]] of France. Today Feuillet works as the head of Trait Research at [[Bayer CropScience]] where she is actively trying to decrypt the remaining 20 wheat chromosomes so as to identify and manipulate traits that would help eliminate biotic and abiotic stressors that inhibit the yield of wheat in the changing environment. She is also the head of the project, Breedwheat, which works to manipulate the wheat genome to improve the yield of wheat in the changing environment due to [[global warming]] because it is a basic food source for upwards of 2 billion people worldwide. ==Education and Early Life== Catherine Feuillet was born in [[Orléans]],{{cite web|url=http://www.breedwheat.fr/files/2011.10.14%20Semeur%20Hebdo%20Catherine%20Feuillet.pdf|title=Catherine Feuillet, une chercheuse en or... vert| author=Jean-Philippe Monjot|language=French|date=14 October 2011|publisher=Le Semeur Hebdo|page=3|accessdate=7 November 2015}} approximately 130 km (80 miles) south of [[Paris]], and attained her education as a [[geneticist]] and [[Molecular biology|molecular biologist]].{{cite web|title=INRA Scientist Catherine Feuillet named AAAS Fellow|url=http://presse.inra.fr/en/Resources/Press-releases/Feuillet-AAAS-Fellow-2011|publisher=Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique|accessdate=6 November 2015|location=Clermont-Ferrand, France|date=23 December 2011}} In 1993, she earned her doctorate at the [[Paul Sabatier University]] in [[Toulouse]], France. Between 1994 and 1997, she completed post-doctoral studies at the Federal Institute for Agroecology in [[Zürich]], studying the genomes of wheat and barley. In 1994 Feuillet finished her thesis on the eucalyptus plant and enzymes used in the wood formation process. She took her thesis to the Swiss Federal Institute for Agroecology in Zürich, Switzerland. She taught two courses as a professor’s assistant and began her work on the wheat genome. At the Swiss Federal Institute for Agroecology she worked in a laboratory under the supervision of Dr. B. Keller to work on structural and evolutionary genomics in wheat and barley.{{cite web|url =https://gmoanswers.com/experts/catherine-feuillet|title =Catherine Feuillet: GMO Answers|last =Feuillet| first =Catherine| date =24 April 2014|website =GMO Answers|publisher =Council for Biotechnology Information| access-date =15 March 2016}} She joined the Institute of Plant Biology at the [[University of Zurich]] as a junior group leader and continued her grain research{{cite web|title=Catherine Feuillet|url=http://pae.criba.edu.ar/paginas/shortbio2010%20feuillet.doc|publisher=Proyecto de Área Estratégica|accessdate=6 November 2015|location=Argentina|date=2011}} investigating the genes responsible for fungal disease resistance. {{Quote box|bgcolor=#FFDEAD|align=right|width=35%| "On me dit que je fais peur aux gens en parlant de sélection de gènes... Mais je ne fais que ce que font les fermiers depuis dix mille ans! Sauf qu’ils le faisaient sans le savoir, par croisements. Maintenant, nous, on veut savoir."
''"They tell me I scare people by talking about gene selection .... But I only do what farmers have been doing for ten thousand years. Except that they did it, without knowing it, by cross-breeding. Now we want to know [what we are doing]."'' {{right| Catherine Feuillet, quoted in 2011}} }} In 2011, she joined the Wheat Initiative, created by the [[G-20 major economies|G20 countries]] to improve global wheat production{{cite news|last1=Foucart|first1=Stéphane|title=Comment faire pousser 60 % de blé en plus en 2050?|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/planete/article/2013/05/17/comment-faire-pousser-60-de-ble-en-plus-en-2050_3289248_3244.html#|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Le Monde|date=17 May 2013|location=Paris, France|language=French}} and that same year was awarded a Fellowship by the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]].{{cite web|title=AAAS Members Elected as Fellows|url=http://www.aaas.org/news/aaas-members-elected-fellows-0|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science|accessdate=6 November 2015|location=Washington, DC|date=23 December 2011}} Feuillet received the Jean Dufrenoy Prize from the [[Académie d'Agriculture]] of France in 2012{{cite web|title=Prix Jean Dufrenoy|url=http://www.academie-agriculture.fr/prix-medailles/prix-jean-dufrenoy|publisher=Académie d'agriculture de France|accessdate=6 November 2015|location=Paris, France|language=French}} and in 2013, she joined [[Bayer CropScience]] as head of the Trait Research Department.{{cite news|title=Borlaug Dialogue International Symposium|url=https://2014borlaugdialoguea.sched.org/speaker/catherine_feuillet.1srnwy4z#.VjwTzOK2oVI|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Borlaug Dialogue|date=17 October 2014|location=Des Moines, Iowa}} In 2014, her team at IWGSC successfully completed sequencing wheat chromosome 3B and by utilizing a technique called [[shotgun sequencing]] they were able to publish a draft of the entire wheat genome sequence. The draft is only 53% accurate and complete mapping will take approximately two more years, provided funding for the project is attained. [[File:University-933660.jpg|thumb|The University of Zurich in Switzerland]] ==Early Research and Awards== In 2004, she joined the [[Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique]] (National Institute of Agricultural Research) (INRA) in [[Clermont-Ferrand]], France, as the research director of the Genetics, Diversity and Ecophysiology of Cereals Department. In 2005, she joined the International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium (IWGSC), an international effort in which she serves as a co-chair whose goal is to sequence the genome of wheat.{{cite news|last1=Huet|first1=Sylvestre|title=Il faut ouvrir la boîte noire du génome des blés|url=http://www.liberation.fr/sciences/2013/03/28/il-faut-ouvrir-la-boite-noire-du-genome-des-bles_892066|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Liberation|date=28 March 2013|location=France|language=French}} She was also appointed as the chair of the European Triticeae Genomics Initiative (ETGI) in 2005.{{cite web|title=Catherine Feuillet distinguée par l'Académie des sciences|url=http://jobs.inra.fr/A-la-une/Prix-et-distinctions/Catherine-Feuillet-distinguee-par-l-Academie-des-sciences|publisher=Institute National de la Recherche Agronomique|accessdate=6 November 2015|location=Clermont-Ferrand, France|language=French|date=24 November 2009}} In 2008, Feuillet's team published in the journal, ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'', the first mapping results of the wheat chromosome 3B, which is the largest{{cite news|title=Genetic Researchers Unveil Draft Sequence of Wheat Genome|url=http://www.sci-news.com/genetics/science-draft-sequence-wheat-genome-02069.html|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Sci-News|date=18 July 2014|location=Orange County, California}} of the 21 chromosomes of wheat.{{cite news|last1=Gonzalez|first1=Sarah|title=Wanted: $13 million to unlock the wheat genome|url=http://www.agri-pulse.com/Wanted-13-million-to-unlock-the-wheat-genome-03112015.asp|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=Agri-Pulse Communications|location=Camdenton, Missouri|date=11 March 2015}} That same year, she joined the International Triticeae Mapping Initiative (ITMI) to assist with planning and coordination of research projects.{{cite web|title=The International Triticeae Mapping Initiative – ITMI|url=http://cereales-vallee.org/data/editor/file/C%C3%A9r%C3%A9ales%20Productions%20agricoles%20durables/fiche_ITMI.pdf|publisher=Céréales Vallée|accessdate=6 November 2015|location=Saint-Beauzire, France|language=French|date=August 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208190540/http://cereales-vallee.org/data/editor/file/C%C3%A9r%C3%A9ales%20Productions%20agricoles%20durables/fiche_ITMI.pdf|archivedate=8 December 2015|df=dmy-all}} On 24 November, 2009 Feuillet received the Prix Foulon from the French Academy of Sciences for her work in deciphering the genome.{{cite news|title=Catherine Feuillet, directrice de recherche à l’Inra|url=http://www.clermont-ferrand.fr/Catherine-Feuillet-directrice-de.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208130054/http://www.clermont-ferrand.fr/Catherine-Feuillet-directrice-de.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=8 December 2015|accessdate=6 November 2015|publisher=TV8|date=24 November 2009|location=Clermont-Ferrand, France|language=French}} That same year, she was also awarded the gold ''Trophée de la Femme'' for her research and then on 10 September 2010, received the insignia of Chevalier of the [[Legion of Honour]] from the INRA.{{cite web|title=Catherine Feuillet reçoit la Légion d'honneur|url=http://www6.ara.inra.fr/umr1095/Actualites/Legion-d-honneur-Catherine-Feuillet|publisher=Institute National de la Recherche Agronomique|accessdate=6 November 2015|location=Clermont-Ferrand, France|language=French|date=13 September 2010}} ==Wheat Genome Sequencing== [[File:Weizenähre Detailansicht.JPG|thumb|Weizenähre Detailansicht]] In 2004 Feuillet began her work on the wheat genome, decrypting the chromosome 3B. Decrypting the chromosome took 4 years, but in 2008 she finally finished and presented the chromosome to the scientific community in the journal Science. This required making a map of one of the 42 chromosomes, placing over 1400 molecular markers throughout its 995 million base pairs. The work had never been done before because the sequence was large and had extreme amounts of repetitive sequences, which make it difficult to match the pieces together in the sequence. The wheat genome was also difficult to sequence because of its chromosome arrangement: the plant has three sets of chromosomes in one nucleus, called a hexaploid arrangement. The chromosome she chose to sequence, 3B, is the largest chromosome on the entire genome, and is by itself double the size of the entire rice genome.{{cite web| url =http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2008/10/giant-leap-wheat-genome | title =A Giant Leap for Wheat Genome | last =Pennisi | first =Elizabeth | date =2 October 2008 | website =Science | publisher =American Association for the Advancement of Science | access-date =14 March 2016 | quote = }} In early 2016, the IWGSC announced that they had assembled, using de novo shotgun techniques, a high quality reference sequence of the bread wheat genome. The project was made possible through a collaboration of IPK Gatersleben in Germany, the University of Saskatchewan’s Crop Development Centre in Canada, Kansas State University, and the Global Institute of Food Security in Canada.{{cite web| url =http://www.wheatgenome.org/News/Press-releases/Wheat-Genome-Sequencing-Gets-Major-Boost | title =Wheat Genome Sequencing Gets Major Boost | last = | first = | date =6 January 2016| website = | publisher =International Wheat Genome Sequencing Consortium | access-date =15 March 2016 | quote = }} This “shotgun” approach allows the sequencing to be done very quickly, but it can be rather inaccurate as compared to the “map-based” sequence Feuillet used when she sequenced the 3B chromosome. The shotgun approach is approximated to be 94% accurate, while the rest of the chromosome is about 53% accurate using the second approach. This data from the second approach, released in collaboration with the IWGSC, will be used along with the physical-map based approach to individual chromosomes, including Feuillet’s sequencing of 3B, to produce the full genome by 2017. Sequencing the wheat genome completely is important for producers all over the world. Wheat currently makes up more than 20% of all calories consumed in the world, and as the global population increases, so does the need for wheat. Recently, however, wheat production has been stagnating because technological advances can’t keep up with negative economic and natural factors.{{cite web|url=http://www.agprofessional.com/news/commentary-working-improve-productivity-gap-wheat-crops | title =Working To Improve the Productivity Gap in Wheat Crops | last =Feuillet | first =Catherine | date =9 December 2015 | website =Farm Journal, Inc. | access-date =14 March 2016 | quote = }} The total demand for wheat is expected to increase by 70 percent by the year 2050—an increase of about 1.6 percent per year (Gonzalez). By sequencing the genome, scientists will be able to research ways to improve the efficiency of the crop through means like genetic engineering, which could allow production of wheat in areas with low nutrient levels. ==Current Research== Feuillet is still continuing her work on sequencing wheat genomes today in order to contribute to the field of agronomy. Her work focuses on genes that would have medicinal advancements that would help prevent illnesses in plants. To continue her work on the wheat genome Feuillet now heads the project, Breedwheat, which receives 34 million euros annually and has a team of 128 researchers. The project is trying to manipulate wheat to adapt to the changing environment caused by global warming. Because wheat is a necessary and basic food for 30% of the global population, Feuillet found it especially important to ensure the survival of wheat as a food source as the human species influences the global conditions at an ever more rapid pace. Feuillet currently leads Trait Research at Bayer CropScience and is working on “identifying the genes responsible for yield and resistance to biotic and abiotic stresses.”{{cite web | url =http://www.research.bayer.com/en/wheat-makers.aspx | title =The Wheat Makers - Research Magazine | website =The Bayer Scientific Magazine | publisher =Bayer CropScience | access-date =15 March 2016 | quote = }} Since upwards of 2 billion people worldwide rely on wheat a main food source, researchers at Bayer CropScience like Catherine Feuillet, Steve Patterson, and Edward Souza are working on increasing the yield of wheat without increasing the amount of land required for that yield. Feuillet’s work at decoding the wheat genome is essential in increasing the yield because once decoded, the genome could be modified so that yield inhibitors could be abolished. This information is then used by Souza, the Head of Wheat Breeding Research at Bayer CropScience, to develop markers to find the genes that produce the desired trait. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Feuillet, Catherine}} [[Category:French geneticists]] [[Category:French molecular biologists]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French women scientists]] [[Category:Genetic engineering and agriculture]] [[Category:Women botanists]] [[Category:Women geneticists]] [[Category:Women molecular biologists]] [[Category:Légion d'honneur recipients]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Association for the Advancement of Science]] [[Category:People from Orléans]] [[Category:20th-century French botanists]] [[Category:21st-century French botanists]] [[Category:20th-century French scientists]] [[Category:21st-century French scientists]] [[Category:20th-century women scientists]] [[Category:21st-century women scientists]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]]
